'Indian religions', also called 'dharmic religions', are the religions that
originated in the Indian subcontinent; namely Hinduism, Jainism, Early Buddhism
and Sikhism. Adams, C. J., [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-38030/classification-of-
religions Classification of religions: Geographical], EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica,
2007. Accessed: 15 July 2010 These religions are also classified as
Eastern religions. Although Indian religions are connected through the history
of India, they constitute a wide range of religious communities, and are not
confined to the Indian subcontinent.

Evidence attesting to prehistoric religion in the Indian subcontinent derives
from scattered Mesolithic rock paintings. The documented history of Indian
religions begins with ancient Hinduism or the historical Vedic religion, the
religious practices of the early Indo-Aryans, which were collected and later
redacted into the [[Vedas]]. The period of the composition, redaction and
commentary of these texts is known as the Vedic period, which lasted from
roughly 1750 to 500 BCE.

Jainism and Buddhism belong to the sramana tradition. The Shramana was an
ancient Indian religious movement, parallel to, but separate from, Vedic
tradition and was responsible for the related concepts of [[saá¹sÄra]] (the cycle
of birth and death) and [[moksha]] (liberation from that cycle).

Hinduism is divided into numerous denominations, primarily Shaivism, Shaktism,
Vaishnavism, Smarta and much smaller groups like the conservative Shrauta. Hindu
reform movements are more recent.

Sikhism was founded in the 15th century on the teachings of Guru Nanak and the
nine successive Sikh Gurus in Northern India. The vast
majority of its adherents originate in the Punjab region.
headings: Status of non-Hindus in the Republic of India
